tossups.question: 1,2-addition of this element to alpha-beta unsaturated compounds is achieved using the reagent PTAB (“p-tab”). Diphenyl ethers bound to between one and ten atoms of this element are used as flame retardants. The Wohl-Ziegler reaction adds this element in an allylic (“al-LIL-lick”) or benzylic position, and a reagent containing this element bonded to the nitrogen atom in succinimide (“sook-SIN-e-mide”) is employed as a source in that reaction. This element’s silver salt exhibits both Frenkel and Schottky defects and is widely used in (*) films for photography. Anti-Markovnikov addition of this element’s binary acid to an alkene may be achieved in the presence of peroxide. A solution of this element turns colorless in the presence of double bonds. For 10 points, name this halogen that is a liquid at room temperature, with symbol Br.

One character in this essay is described as an “organism that has been under the shadow of the rock these million years” and minces liver to study anemia. This essay’s author complains that novelists do not adequately describe food before imagining people humming Victorian poetry at luncheon parties. This essay’s narrator makes an angry doodle of “Professor von X,” calls herself “Mary Seton, Mary Beton, Mary Carmichael,” and was not allowed to walk on the (*) grass at her school. That narrator of this essay jokingly asks if Charles Biron is hiding in the room before saying “Chloe liked Olivia.” One woman in this essay became pregnant and killed herself since she had no opportunity to write like her brother Shakespeare. For 10 points, name this essay by Virginia Woolf that identified the title thing, along with money, as essential for women to write fiction.

People form nine-tiered human pyramids to celebrate this event as part of Dahi Handi. Book Nine of the Bhagavata Purana ends by describing this event, which was prompted when a god pulled a black and a white hair from his head. A king intended to throw the central figure of this event into a stone but he mistakenly grabbed an incarnation of Yogamaya. The Rasa lila (“RAW-suh leela”) dance is performed as part of a celebration of this event called (*) Janmashtami (“juhn-MAWSH-tuh-mee”). The birth of Balarama preceded this event, which the king of Mathura tries to prevent out of fear of being overthrown. Vrindavan is revered as holy for being the site where this event occurred. Nanda Baba and Yashoda care for the central figure of this event after he is given away by his parents Devaki and Vasudeva to protect him from Kamsa. For 10 points, name this event which brought the eight avatar of Vishnu into the world as a butter-stealing infant.
tossups.answer: birth of Krishna [or Krishna Janmashtami until read; or Gokulashtami]

tossups.question: Ivory artifacts found in this country include a tusk carving at the British Museum depicting Swimming Reindeer and a fragmentary Venus with cross-hatched hair. A charcoal Venus is paired with a “Sorcerer” figure at a site in this country that was explored in a 3D documentary titled for its “Forgotten Dreams” and directed by Werner Herzog. A site in this country features a man with a bird’s head lying next to a disemboweled (*) bison in its “Shaft” scene. In 1940, four teenagers discovered that site in this country, which features a recurring motif of rows of black dots and depictions of the “Red Cow” and “Chinese Horse.” A site in this country depicts a seventeen-foot long figure in its Axial Gallery, which is connected to the Hall of the Bulls. For 10 points, Paleolithic cave paintings can be found in which country’s Lascaux (“la-skoh”) caves?

Members of this force received a ticker tape parade on Broadway when it visited the United States in 1863 in the midst of the American Civil War. Cornelius Cruys, a future leader of this force, met its founder while he was working undercover at a Dutch shipyard. Remnants of this force sought refuge with France in Bizerte, Tunisia while carrying soldiers under the command of General Wrangel. En route to a new base, this force nearly sparked a war scare with (*) Britain when it fired on fishing boats at Dogger Bank. Wireless communication allowed another force to “cross the T” against this force in a crushing defeat at Tsushima. A shot from this force’s ship Aurora signalled the beginning of the assault on the Winter Palace during the October Revolution. For 10 points, name this force commanded for a time by Admiral Fyodor Ushakov and founded by Peter the Great.
tossups.answer: Imperial Russian Navy [or Russian Fleet; anti-prompt on Black Sea Fleet or Baltic Fleet or Pacific Fleet or White Fleet with “can you be less specific?”; do not accept “Soviet Navy” or equivalents; do not accept “Russian Army” or “White Army”]

tossups.question: Project FAMOUS and the RISE project were expeditions exploring this phenomenon in the 1970s. The sites of this phenomenon experience high temperatures and low seismic wave speed. The lack of discovery of marine sediment older than 200 million years is evidence for this phenomenon. Geomagnetic reversals have been observed by analyzing ferromagnetic (*) “stripes” of anomalies present as a result of this phenomena as part of the Morley-Vine-Matthews hypothesis. It is caused by convection currents in the asthenosphere and is one of the driving forces behind continental drift. For 10 points, name this phenomenon which occurs at divergent plate boundaries in which new oceanic crust is created when magma rises and cools.

One poem in this language says that “these seas shall take revenge” and “I mourn the sun and I mourn the years that come.” This language of “The Monogram” was spoken by a poet who wrote “[I]n a more perfect society, / someone else made just like me / is certain to appear and act freely” in “Hidden Things,” a reference to his homosexuality. That poet wrote “say goodbye to her, the Alexandria you are losing” in this language. In another work in this language, he asked “Why are the (*) senators sitting there without legislating?” and laments “Those people were a kind of solution.” Those poems in this lanugage are “The God Abandons Antony” and “Waiting for the Barbarians.” Another author used this language to write about a lignite miner who seduces Madame Hortense. For 10 points, name this language, spoken by Odysseus Elytis, Constantine Cavafy, and Nikos Kazantzakis.

In the first movement of this symphony, the coda begins at a forte statement of the main theme in the unexpected key of D-flat major, followed by a fortissimo statement in C major. The initial theme of the first movement lands on a tonally ambiguous C-sharp in the cellos, followed immediately by the violins playing offbeat quarter note G’s above. The composer had previously used the main theme of the fourth movement in the seventh of a set of (*) 12 Contredanses and in the ballet The Creatures of Prometheus. This symphony, which traditionally marks the beginning of its composer’s middle period, features a second movement funeral march and was published with the subtitle “composed to celebrate the memory of a great man.” For 10 points, name this symphony in E-flat by Ludwig van Beethoven, originally dedicated to Napoleon.
tossups.answer: Beethoven’s Symphony No. 3 [or Eroica or Beethoven’s Opus 55; accept just Symphony No. 3 or Opus 55 after “Beethoven” is read; prompt on Symphony No. 3 or Opus 55 before “Beethoven” is read]

tossups.question: One of these people built a Buddhist temple dedicated to Guanyin at Tyr and established the Nurgan Regional Military Commission. One leader of these people issued a manifesto that cited undue favoritism for the Yehe and Hada clans as a casus belli. These people successfully repelled a four-pronged enemy assault at the Battle of Sarhū and declared the Seven Grievances before attacking their southern neighbor. Following the suicide of the (*) Chongzen Emperor, Wu Sangui allowed these people through the Shanhai Pass. The Aisin Gioro clan ruled these people, whose queue hairstyle was imposed on native Han Chinese under punishment of death. Formerly known as the Jurchen, these people were organized into the Eight Banners under Nurhaci (“nur-HAW-chee”). For 10 points, name this ethnic group which invaded the Ming Dynasty in the 17th century and founded the Qing Dynasty.
tossups.answer: Manchus [accept Jurchen until “manifesto,” then prompt until mentioned; prompt on Qing before mentioned]

tossups.question: This thinker argued that the development of a human's individual mental faculties, or "subjective culture," could only be shaped by societal institutions, the "objective culture." Along with Leopold von Wiese (“VEE-suh”), this thinker focused on the study of recurrent social interactions through which one could formulate a "geometry of social life," thus pioneering the subfield of formal sociology. He characterized the overwhelming barrage of stimuli in a city as a (*) "tragedy of culture" against which residents developed a "blasé attitude." In his most famous work, this thinker reflected that the economic exchange relationship requires trust and that transitioning from barter systems to a singular medium of exchange was necessary for modernity. For 10 points, name this sociologist who wrote "The Stranger," The Metropolis and Mental Life, and The Philosophy of Money.

In an Emily Dickinson poem named for this animal, the narrator gives water to one that “moaned for drink.” One author described these animals “from the forests” singing and throwing away guns in The Four Zoas and called them “wiser than the horses of instruction.” In one work, these “denizens of a world of green” “pace in sleek chivalric certainty” and are sewn by a woman oppressed by “the massive weight of [a] wedding band.” Another poem named for these animals describes a time “when the stars threw down their spears / and water’d heaven with their tears.” An (*) Adrienne Rich poem is named for “Aunt Jennifer’s” [these creatures]. Another work named for this animal asks “What the hammer? What the chain” and “Did he who made the Lamb make thee?” For 10 points, name this animal which is “burning bright / in the forests of the night” in a poem by William Blake.

The Go model of this process ignores all non-native contacts. Classical two-state theories of this process do not predict “rollover.” Intermediates in this process are often studied by using pulsed exchange in a stopped-flow apparatus. When this process is aberrant, the ERAD pathway is activated. Intermediates in this process adopt a molten globule configuration after a burst phase. The fact that this process cannot proceed through a blind search is the subject of (*) Levinthal’s paradox, suggesting that this process proceeds downhill through an energy funnel. Heat shock proteins and other chaperones assist with this process, during which disulfide bonds may be formed. For 10 points, name this process by which a polymer of amino acids assumes a three-dimensional conformation.
tossups.answer: protein folding [prompt on translation; prompt on protein synthesis; prompt on peptide synthesis; prompt on common-language equivalents]

tossups.question: Angus Graham performed an analysis of two sections, known as the Canons and the Explanations of the Canons, of a major philosophical text from this modern-day country. That philosophical text from this country also contains a chapter titled Names and Objects, which introduced the first known logical analysis of propositions in this country’s philosophy. The concept of “universal concern” is central to a philosophical school from this country, which used the tests of precedent, veracity, and utility as its three “standards.” A different philosophical school in this country advocated for an (*) alignment between words and actions known as the “rectification of names,” while a third school of political philosophy from this country was based on the three pillars of power, law, and the management of the bureaucracy. For 10 points, identify this country that was home to Mohism, Legalism, and Confucianism.
tossups.answer: China [do not accept “Taiwan” or “Republic of China”]

tossups.question: One hundred years after this event, Michael Hirsch identified six unidentified victims buried together in the Cemetery of the Evergreens. Some victims of this event earlier participated in the Uprising of the 20,000. Joseph Zito and Gaspar Mortillalo rescued victims of this event, some of whom were accused of (*) memorizing their statements during cross-examination by Max Steuer. Rose Schneiderman vowed not to “talk good fellowship” in a speech after this event, and this event prompted Frances Perkins to become executive secretary of a new Committee on Safety. The ILGWU attracted support after this event, in which locked doors on the top floors of the Asch Building prevented many of the victims from escaping. For 10 points, name this 1911 fire in which employer negligence killed over one hundred women in a clothing factory.

This event is notable for the longest running sponsorship in sports history due to its association with Slazenger. At the 2012 iteration of this event, Yaroslava Shvedova became the only player to date to complete a golden set in the main draw of a Major. John Isner played Nicholas Mahut in a record (*) eleven-hour long match at this event in 2010. A sterling silver salver called the Venus Rosewater Dish is awarded to the Ladies’ Singles champion at this event. Strawberries and cream are a traditionally consumed refreshment at this event, and a retractable roof was added to the Centre Court at this event in 2009. For 10 points, name this Grand Slam tennis event played annually at grass courts in London.

In the overture to this opera, the andante section ends with a five-note “motto” theme to which one of the characters later sings the title of the opera aloud, just before the final scene. It is not by Bellini, but in act 2, a soprano begs her absent lover to forgive her in the aria “Per pietà, ben mio perdona.” At the end of act 1, a maid disguised as a doctor appears to revive the unconscious male leads with a magnet. As those male leads (*) pretend to head off to war, they are wished good fortune in the trio “Soave sia il vento.” This opera was its composer’s final collaboration with librettist Lorenzo da Ponte. The plot is set in motion when Don Alfonso proposes a test of Fiordiligi (“fyor-dee-lee-gee”) and Dorabella’s fidelity. For 10 points, name this opera in which Ferrando and Guglielmo (“gul-YEL-mo”) disguise themselves as Albanians to seduce the other’s fiancée, composed by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
tossups.answer: Così fan tutte, ossia La scuola degli amanti [accept “Thus do they all” or “Women are like that” or other reasonable translations even though it’s always referred to by the Italian title] (The maid is Despina.)

tossups.question: One dwelling of this man had its peristyle painted red by Communist performance artists in the 1960s; that building featured Golden, Silver, Iron, and Aeneas Gates. This ruler proposed the Peace of Nisibus to end the Roman-Sassanian War, and one of his policies provoked a schism between traditors and Donatists. This ruler’s palace forms the modern-day center of (*) Split, Croatia, and he appointed the leaders Galerius and Constantius Chlorus. This man defeated Carinus in the Battle of the Margus to become emperor and end the Crisis of the Third Century, and he attempted to check inflation via the Edict on Maximum Prices. Continuing a policy ignored by his predecessor Gallienus, this ruler ordered the last and bloodiest persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire. For 10 points, name this Roman emperor who established the tetrarchy.

A character in this novel reminisces on how he was once kicked by a guard until he passed a kidney stone. That character in this novel is later shot in the eye with a slingshot. After asking a man why he drinks alcohol, one character in this novel is told that “Every other sin is a variation of theft.” One character in this novel takes writing classes at San Jose State University and meets his wife while selling goods at a flea market. Earlier in this novel, that character plants money under his friend’s mattress to get him kicked out of his house. One character says (*) “For you, a thousand times over” after he performs this novel’s title action for Sohrab, the son of the man who was raped by Assef in an alleyway after the protagonist of this novel failed to intervene. For 10 points, Amir flees with his father from Afghanistan and Hassan retrieves the title objects in what novel by Khaled Hosseini?

In the Jangar Epic, one of these objects named Aram was used by Jangar to attack Altan Gheej. After Soorapadman disguised himself as a mango tree during his battle with Murugan, he split the tree in half using one of these objects. One of these objects formerly belonging to the king of Persia was required to be left in a pot of water, similar to the one owned by Celtchar. The process of kuniumi was carried out by (*) Izanami and Izanagi who used one of these objects adorned with jewels called Ame-no-nuhoko. Kartikeya wielded one of these objects named Vel, while another one made from the bones of a sea monster was given to Cú Chulainn. One of these objects created by the dwarf Dvalinn always hit its target. For 10 points, name this weapon, exemplified by Odin’s Gungnir, whose varieties include the trident and javelin.
tossups.answer: spear [or lance; accept trident or javelin before mentioned]

tossups.question: David Jeanmaire and Richard van Duyne used this technique to examine pyridine molecules on a silver electrode, and observed a signal 5 orders of magnitude greater than expected from predictions. The main contributor to that strong signal is now believed to be the concentration of energy in localized surface plasmon resonances. It does not necessarily use infrared light, but the gross selection rule for this technique requires that a molecule have anisotropic (*) polarizability. Nanoparticles adsorbed onto surfaces are especially sensitive to the surface-enhanced form of this technique. Rayleigh-scattered light must be separated out using notch filters in this technique to observe Stokes and anti-Stokes wavelength shifts caused by inelastic scattering. For 10 points, name this form of spectroscopy named after an Indian physicist.
tossups.answer: Raman spectroscopy [or Raman scattering; accept surface-enhanced Raman scattering or SERS]

bonuses.leadin: In the 16th century, artists in this country produced portraits emphasizing exaggerated facial expressions known as tronies. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Frans Hals (The initials “JL” referred to the painting’s actual artist, Judith Leyster.)
parts: Name this country. This country was also home to a genre of group portraiture featuring guild’s regents sitting around a table, including one in which the figures inspect cloth samples.
In this type of portrait, the subject is depicted from a side view. A portrait of Charles I in Three Positions depicts the title ruler from the front, a three-quarters view, and in this manner.

This Dutch painter was known for his portraits in a slapdash alla prima style with clearly visible brushstrokes. He was the attributed artist of The Happy Couple until a monogram with the initials “JL” was discovered.

bonuses.leadin: In the Between Two Ferns film, Zach Galifianakis asks this actor: “I notice that you’re wearing a shirt. Is everything OK?” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: “Alright, alright, alright” [do not accept or prompt on answers with the wrong number of “alrights”]
parts: Name this actor lauded by NYMag as “Hollywood’s Most Shirtless Man,” who showed off his physique in Magic Mike and The Wedding Planner. His dramatic films include The Lincoln Lawyer and Dallas Buyers Club.

McConaughey received critical acclaim for his performance as this Texas investigator in the HBO series True Detective. This pessimistic character is partners with the Woody Harrelson-played Marty Hart.
McConaughey’s most famous line in a film is this repetitive phrase uttered in the 1993 coming-of-age film Dazed and Confused; this phrase has become a catchphrase of sorts for McConaughey.

bonuses.leadin: The superhydrophilicity of this material has made it popular for self-cleaning glass. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: titanium dioxide [or titania; or titanium white; or TiO2]
parts: Name this photocatalyst. The catalytic properties of this substance were discovered by Akira Fujishima, who used this substance to generate clean hydrogen gas from water.
UV light commonly generates these highly-reactive species, which have an unpaired electron. Reaction of these species are commonly depicted using fishhook arrows.

Another common photocatalyst is Fenton’s reagent, which consists of Fe2+ ions in this solvent. This solvent undergoes disproportionation reactions to generate two different oxygen-containing radicals.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker developed a hierarchy of intellects at the top of which was the “active intellect,” and was known as the “Second Teacher,” for his commentaries on the Organon of Aristotle. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Islamic philosopher whose own works on politics include The Virtuous City and The Attainment of Happiness.
Al-Ghazali objected to al-Farabi’s account of this concept on the grounds that it was too abstract, whereas in the Qur’an it was described as a real place.

Al-Farabi was part of a school of philosophers known as mashsha’un (“mesh-SHEH-   -oon”), which roughly translates to this English term. This English term names the school of philosophy founded by Aristotle himself.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. After concluding “the war was over and there was no place in particular to go,” a man does this while imagining telling his father about how he almost won the Silver Star. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: driving a car around a lake
parts: Name this action which Norman Bowker takes repeatedly in the short story “Speaking of Courage” which is juxtaposed with the image of Kiowa drowning in a shit field.

“Speaking of Courage” forms the center of this Tim O’Brien short story collection, named after a litany of objects including “can openers, pocket knives, heat tabs, wristwatches, dog tags, mosquito repellent, chewing gum.”
Tim O’Brien wrote about this war in “The Things They Carried” and Going After Cacciato, in which Paul Berlin and Sarkin Aung Wan fall into a series of tunnels.

bonuses.leadin: Lighthouses on this waterway’s islet of Snipe were repeatedly destroyed in a border disagreement. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Pope John Paul II [do not accept or prompt on “John” or “Paul”]
parts: Name this strait mapped by Admiral Philip Parker King and Captain Pringle Stokes. A dispute over this body of water led to a war scare that began with the launching of Operation Soberanía.

The threat of war between Argentina and Chile over the Beagle Channel led this Eastern European Pope to send Antonio Samorè to intervene in the crisis and he later mediated the disagreement through the Act of Montevideo.
The Beagle Channel is named for the ship on which this British naturalist surveyed South America before authoring On the Origin of Species.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the heathen religion inspired by Norse paganism, Asatru, for 10 points each:
parts: Practitioners celebrating sumbel offer their first toast of mead to this giant, from whom Odin obtained the mead of poetry while his niece Gunnlöd was guarding it.
The name Asatru comes from this race of gods including Odin and Thor who fought a war with the Vanir.
The Asatru faith teaches this many Noble Virtues. There are this many worlds in Norse cosmology which are all connected to Yggdrasil.

bonuses.leadin: One character in a novel by this man thinks that evolution can cause animals to turn into people and thus panics when he sees a dead horse with a note declaring the bearer died ‘an honorable Soviet’ next to it. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Heart of a Dog [ or Sobachye syerdtsye; accept A Dog’s Heart; accept any English translation that is identical to Heart of a Dog or A Dog’s Heart if you ignore the articles “a” and “the”] (By Mikhail Bulgakov.)
parts: Name this author of Moscow 2042 who parodied socialist realism in The Life and Extraordinary Adventures of Private Ivan Chonkin.
In this novel, Dr. Bormental uses a pituitary and testicle transfusion to turn Sharik into Polygraph Polygraphovich.
This George Orwell novel about Napoleon taking over the title establishment ends with creatures looking “from pig to man, and from man to pig...but already it was impossible to say which was which.”

bonuses.leadin: Fictitious forces arise when these constructs accelerate. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these constructs that are used to solve physics problems; inertial ones have a constant velocity.

A rotating reference frame such as a swerving car creates the illusion of this fictitious force, which appears to push objects outward. This force and the Coriolis force are both proportional to angular velocity.

Because Earth moves around the Sun as it rotates, it is more convenient for astronomers to use this system of time rather than solar time. This system is based on the rotation of Earth relative to the fixed reference frame of the stars.

bonuses.leadin: This soldier’s favorite pastime was drinking beer, smoking, and wrestling his comrades, and he even learned to salute. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ursine corporal of the Polish II Corps who served in the Battle of Monte Cassino by carrying crates of artillery ammunition.

Wojtek was purchased by an exiled Polish soldier in this country’s city of Hamadan. The British and Soviets jointly invaded this country in Operation Countenance in fear that the Abadan refinery would fall into Nazi hands.
Wojtek was promoted to corporal for his service in the Battle of Monte Cassino in this country, which joined the Allies after King Victor Emmanuel III dismissed Benito Mussolini and sued for peace.

bonuses.leadin: This platform-independent protocol is used to transfer requests and files that answer those requests over the Internet. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this protocol that allows the Web server and the client to communicate. The name of this protocol is seen before the colon slash slash in a web address.

This type of HTTP request retrieves information from a server. This request limits the query string to a predefined number of characters that varies from server to server and if the query string exceeds the limit, a POST request must be used.

This other protocol, named for the fact that it is not specific to any OS or programming language, is often used to generate dynamic web content via its namesake scripts. This protocol was developed by the National Center for Supercomputing Applications for use with the HTTPd Web server.

bonuses.leadin: This event occurred during the reign of Zedekiah after Jeconiah had been removed from power. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: destruction of the First Temple of Jerusalem [accept Solomon’s Temple in place of  “First Temple”; accept synonyms for “destruction”; prompt on answers not specifying which temple was destroyed; prompt on fall of Jerusalem or synonyms for fall]
parts: Identify this event that occurred around 587 BC at the beginning of the Babylonian invasion, remembered on Tisha B’av. The Talmud describes how a hand caught a set of keys that were thrown from the roof of a building during this event.

The blood of a man with this name, the son of Jehoiada, finally settled into the ground during the destruction. The penultimate book of the Old Testament was written by a prophet with this name who pushed for the construction of the Second Temple with Haggai.
The First Temple was built by Solomon after this man, his father, made initial plans for it but was forbidden by God to build it.

bonuses.leadin: A 2017 en banc review by the D.C. Circuit Court reversed Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s ruling that the head of this agency could be fired by the President at will. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
parts: Name this independent agency whose first director, Richard Cordray, was installed by Barack Obama using a controversial recess appointment. Richard Shelby and Jeb Hensarling pushed for this agency to be led by an executive board.
This 2010 law passed to address the Great Recession created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and introduced the Volcker Rule banning proprietary trading by commercial banks.

This Harvard Law professor proposed the CFPB and oversaw its creation as an Assistant to the President. After leaving the White House, this woman defeated Scott Brown to win a Massachusetts Senate seat.

bonuses.leadin: This theater style uses mie poses and special effects called keren. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this theater style which was begun by women in the 1600s but later became all-male. It is often considered more avant-garde and dramatic than a similar style.
Kabuki theater, as well as noh, kyogen, and bunraku, hails from this country, home of the playwright Chikamatsu Monzaemon.
This exaggerated, dramatic style of makeup is used in kabuki; in it, red represents heroes, blue represents villains, and brown represents demons.

bonuses.leadin: This composer established the IRCAM institute for avant-garde music at the Pompidou Centre. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this conductor and composer, who used the resources of IRCAM to write pieces such as Répons for orchestra, soloists, and electronics. This advocate of total serialism also wrote Pli selon pli.
Boulez’s piece …explosante-fixe…, which he later re-orchestrated with electronics, was originally written as a tribute to this composer of The Rite of Spring and Symphony of Psalms.
This German composer’s Studie II was the first piece of electronic music to be published in score. He also composed Kontakte and a cycle of seven operas entitled Licht.

bonuses.leadin: A Punch cartoon titled “Preferential Treatment” depicts this piece of legislation being pushed in a stroller by a man who would later give the “Mansion House” speech as Prime Minister. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: King George V [prompt on King George]
parts: Name this 1909 bill aimed at funding social welfare through unprecedented taxes on Britain’s wealthy. The House of Lords’ veto of this bill sparked a constitutional stand-off.

The Asquith ministry responded by passing the Parliamentary Act of 1911 removing the Lords’ veto on money bills, supported by this monarch’s threat to install four hundred Liberal peers. This King changed his dynastic name to Windsor so it would sound less German during World War I.
The People’s Budget was championed by David Lloyd George and this President of the Board of Trade. This Liberal-turned-Conservative served as prime minister during World War II.

bonuses.leadin: The frictional form of this quantity can be caused by people entering the workforce or looking for a different job. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this rate that measures the percentage of the labor force which has actively looked for work within the past four weeks.

Unemployment often occurs in the short term when this type of wage, which is higher than the equilibrium rate, is distributed in order to achieve objectives like attracting new candidates or maintaining employee loyalty.

Specific term required. Incentives to motivate employee effort may be pursued via reciprocity, gift exchange, or the Shapiro-Stiglitz model. The Shapiro-Stiglitz model disincentivizes this specific behavior by dispensing an efficiency wage to create an opportunity cost for employees looking to switch jobs.

bonuses.leadin: This "seedy solipsist" meets Mr. Neary, who claims he has "apmonia," or the ability to stop his heart. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character, who falls in love with a prostitute named Celia and plays chess with Mr. Endon, who he meets while working at a mental hospital in London.
This Irish author of Murphy is better known for creating the characters Vladimir and Estragon in Waiting for Godot.

The character Murphy is also referenced in this Beckett novel, part of a trilogy with Malone Dies and The Unnamable. This novel's title character travels between unnamed towns on a bicycle in search of his possibly-dead mother and is pursued by the detective Moran.

bonuses.leadin: A rare variant of this gene may cause type III hyperlipoproteinemia (“hyper-lie-po-protein-ee-mee-a”) and is believed to play a role in lipid metabolism. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: ApoE [or Apolipoprotein E (“EY-po-LIE-po-protein EE”); or Apolipoprotein E4]
Mini-Mental State Examination [or Mini-Mental Status Examination or MMSE; do not accept “mini-cog”]
parts: Name this gene whose E4 variant is the single largest identified genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

Alzheimer’s disease is a common cause of this condition, in which long-term memory and other cognitive faculties are progressively impaired. This condition’s Lewy body form is often accompanied by hallucinations.
This common screening test for dementia is scored between 0 and 30. This test is sometimes named for Folstein, and one question on it requires drawing a pair of overlapping pentagons.

bonuses.leadin: A light green five-room house was built in this style for the architect's mother Vanna. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: duck and the decorated shed [prompt on “duck and shed”]
parts: Name this style of architecture exemplified by Frank Gehry as well as Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi, who responded to Mies van der Rohe by saying that "less is a bore."

Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown are best known for advocating postmodern architecture in a book about "Learning from" this place, whose "Strip" features a famous starburst sign and many extravagantly decorated casinos.

Exact terms required. Learning from Las Vegas divides its buildings into these types. The first type of building is named for a famously quirky Long Island building which uses its form to advertise; the second type is built functionally but uses vivid signage.
